title: Peter Andre proudly rocks his natural curls after being bullied as a child
text:
Peter’s finally giving his curls the shine they deserve (Picture: Peter Andre, Instagram, PA)

Who knew Peter Andre was hiding a mane of curls this whole time?

The Mysterious Girl singer surprised his Instagram followers by revealing his natural born curls for the first time, and explained how he was embarrassed by them after being bullied as a child.

Peter, 46, is currently sunning himself in Monaco where he attended an event for Caudwell Children’s charity on Sunday evening.

While sprucing himself up before his big night out, the popstar was keen to switch up his look so ditched the straighteners to let his curls free.

And frankly, they deserve the shine.

After starting a poll for his Instagram followers to vote whether he should rock his curls to the party – of course, they voted yes – Peter gave us a close-up of his locks and revealed the heartbreaking story behind them.

‘Do you know, for so many years, I would never wear my hair curly because I got picked on as a kid,’ Peter explained in an Instagram story video.

‘But, I don’t know, I’m trying to adopt them, I think if I just grow it a bit longer, what do you reckon?

‘Thing is I know it’s gotta be that I’m comfortable with it but, at the moment I’m not comfortable with my hair curly. Pretty long, eh?’

We can’t lie Pete, the curls should definitely make a comeback for 2020.

The former I’m a Celebrity star did actually give fans a little glimpse at his curls last week, with a photo which showed them peeking out of his hoodie.

That’s the Peter we’re used to (Picture: PA)

He joked in the caption: ‘#Mysteriouscurl in full force today,’ in reference to his monster ‘90s hit single.

Peter has been working with Caudwell Children for some time and recently opened up about his experience of bullying for one of their campaigns.

In a promo video, Peter said of growing up in Australia: ‘Imagine being in this place that’s got the sunshine, got the beach, got everything you can imagine, but you’re at school and no one wants to talk to you. No one wants to associate themselves with you.

‘When you’re a kid with dark hair, dark eyes, strong English accent, much bigger nose than the kids around you, I was an outcast like you wouldn’t believe.’

He added: ‘I mean, I couldn’t have stuck out more. The term they used in Australia at the time was “w*g”. “W*g’” was used for Greeks, for Italians, people from the Mediterranean.

‘I mean, it happened instantly. Instantly. In our neighbourhood, where we moved into, you’d walk down the street and they’d go, “Get outta here, w*g!’ That’s what it was like”.’
